--- title: 'Time Series Analysis' jupyter: python3 bibliography: references.bib --- ## Introduction [![](https://colab.research.google.com/assets/colab-badge.svg)](https://colab.research.google.com/github/tools4ds/DS701-Course-Notes/blob/main/ds701_book/jupyter_notebooks/26-TimeSeries.ipynb) # Introduction to Time Series ## Definition and examples of time series data ::: {#9bdd1958 .cell execution_count=1} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](26-TimeSeries_files/figure-revealjs/cell-2-output-1.png){width=668 height=302} ::: ::: - A **time series** is a series of data points or observations recorded at different or regular time intervals, e.g. hourly, daily, monthly, quarterly, yearly, etc. - **Time Series Analysis** is the process of analyzing time series data to extract meaningful statistics and other characteristics of the data such as trends, cycles, and seasonal patterns. - **Time-Series Forecasting** is the process of using statistical models to predict future values based on past values. ## Applications ::: {#7374f6d9 .cell execution_count=3} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](26-TimeSeries_files/figure-revealjs/cell-4-output-1.png){width=672 height=376} ::: ::: - **Finance**: Time series analysis is used for stock price prediction, risk management, and economic forecasting. - **Economics**: It helps in understanding economic indicators, GDP growth, and inflation rates. - **Meteorology**: Time series data is crucial for weather forecasting, climate change studies, and analyzing seasonal patterns. - **Healthcare**: Time series analysis is used for analyzing patient data, monitoring disease outbreaks, and predicting patient outcomes. - **Marketing**: Time series analysis is used for analyzing sales data, customer behavior, and predicting future trends. - **Manufacturing**: Time series analysis is used for analyzing production data, monitoring equipment performance, and predicting maintenance needs. ## Components of a Time Series - **Trend**: Long-term movement in the data. "Are car model sales going up or down?" - **Seasonality**: Regular pattern repeating over a known, fixed period. "Do sales of ice cream increase during the summer?" - **Cyclic**: Long-term oscillations not of a fixed period. "Are there long term business cycles in the sales of a product?" - **Irregular/Noise**: Random variation. "Are there random variations in the daily temperature that are not explained by the trend or seasonality?" ## Distinction between time series and other types of data - **Time Series Data**: Data points collected or recorded at specific time intervals. Examples include stock prices, weather data, and sales figures. - **Cross-Sectional Data**: Data collected at a single point in time, representing a snapshot. Examples include survey results and census data. - **Panel Data**: A combination of time series and cross-sectional data, where multiple subjects are observed over time. Examples include longitudinal studies and repeated measures data. Analyzing historical data to answer questions about past behavior 2. Forecasting future values based on past values ::: {.content-visible when-profile="slides"} ## Time and Date Manipulation **Note**: In the course notes version of this chapter, there's a section on time and date manipulation using the `datetime` library and the `pandas` library. ::: ::: {.content-visible when-profile="web"} # Time and Date Manipulation Many time series data sets are indexed by date or time. The python `datetime` library and the `pandas` library provide a powerful set of tools for manipulating time series data. The [Time Series](https://wesmckinney.com/book/time-series) chapter of the book [Python for Data Analysis, 3rd Ed.](https://wesmckinney.com/book/time-series) provides a good overview of these tools. We'll share a few excerpts here. ::: {#99a16f63 .cell execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} import numpy as np import pandas as pd from datetime import datetime now = datetime.now() print(f"Date and time when this cell was executed: {now}") print(f"Year: {now.year}, month: {now.month}, day: {now.day}") delta = now - datetime(2024, 1, 1) print(f"Since beginning of 2024 till when this cell was run there were {delta.days} days and {delta.seconds} seconds.") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Date and time when this cell was executed: 2024-11-19 16:27:56.797172 Year: 2024, month: 11, day: 19 Since beginning of 2024 till when this cell was run there were 323 days and 59276 seconds. ``` ::: ::: You can also convert between strings and datetime. ::: {#4bc1ac5e .cell execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} # string to datetime date_string = "2024-01-01" date_object = datetime.strptime(date_string, "%Y-%m-%d") print(date_object) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 2024-01-01 00:00:00 ``` ::: ::: You can also format datetime objects as strings. ::: {#9c71234c .cell execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code} # datetime to string now_str = now.strftime("%Y-%m-%d") print(now_str) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 2024-11-19 ``` ::: ::: See Table 11.2 in the [book](https://wesmckinney.com/book/time-series) for a list of formatting codes. various characteristics. We'll show a few examples of time series plots and include the code to generate them. ## Time Series Plot We're going to use a dataset of air passengers per month from 1949 to 1960. ::: {#a10d22d3 .cell execution_count=14} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=14} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: Let's look at the time series plot. ::: {#23ac8ca2 .cell execution_count=15} ``` {.python .cell-code} ts = air_passengers['Number of Passengers'] ts.plot(ylabel='Number of Passengers', title='Air Passengers 1949-1960', figsize=(8, 4)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](26-TimeSeries_files/figure-revealjs/cell-16-output-1.png){width=667 height=376} ::: ::: Clearly there are some trends and seasonality in the data. --- One way to accentuate that is to use a two-sided plot. ::: {#43ae5c71 .cell execution_count=16} ``` {.python .cell-code} import matplotlib.pyplot as plt x = air_passengers.index.values y1 = air_passengers['Number of Passengers'].values fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1, figsize=(8, 4)) plt.fill_between(x, y1=y1, y2=-y1, color='tab:blue', alpha=0.2) plt.ylim(-800, 800) plt.title('Air Passengers (Two-Sided View)') plt.hlines(y=0, xmin=x[0], xmax=x[-1], color='black', linewidth=0.5) plt.show() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](26-TimeSeries_files/figure-revealjs/cell-17-output-1.png){width=660 height=357} ::: ::: --- Since there is a clear seasonal pattern in the data, we can plot the data by month. ::: {#3e80ad96 .cell execution_count=17} ``` {.python .cell-code} # Seasonal plot of air_passengers import seaborn as sns # Extract month and year from the index air_passengers['Month'] = air_passengers.index.month air_passengers['Year'] = air_passengers.index.year # Create a seasonal plot plt.figure(figsize=(8, 4)) sns.lineplot(data=air_passengers, x='Month', y='Number of Passengers', hue='Year', palette='tab10') plt.title('Seasonal Plot of Air Passengers') plt.ylabel('Number of Passengers') plt.xlabel('Month') plt.legend(title='Year', bbox_to_anchor=(1.05, 1), loc='upper left') plt.show() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](26-TimeSeries_files/figure-revealjs/cell-18-output-1.png){width=786 height=376} ::: ::: --- The seasonality looks like it is increasing over time, but relatively speaking that might not be the case. We can normalize the data by the first month of each year. ::: {#801f8a50 .cell execution_count=18} ``` {.python .cell-code} # Normalize the number of passengers by the first month of each year air_passengers['Normalized_Passengers'] = air_passengers.groupby('Year')['Number of Passengers'].transform(lambda x: x / x.iloc[0]) # Create a seasonal plot with normalized values plt.figure(figsize=(8, 4)) sns.lineplot(data=air_passengers, x='Month', y='Normalized_Passengers', hue='Year', palette='tab10') plt.title('Seasonal Plot of Air Passengers (Normalized by First Month of Each Year)') plt.ylabel('Normalized Number of Passengers') plt.xlabel('Month') plt.legend(title='Year', bbox_to_anchor=(1.05, 1), loc='upper left') plt.show() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](26-TimeSeries_files/figure-revealjs/cell-19-output-1.png){width=782 height=376} ::: ::: Now the seasonality looks more similar across years, but perhaps it is still increasing a bit over time. --- We can also look at the year-wise box plot. ::: {#a17c85d3 .cell execution_count=19} ``` {.python .cell-code} # Year-wise box plot of air passengers plt.figure(figsize=(8, 4)) sns.boxplot(data=air_passengers, x='Year', y='Number of Passengers', palette='tab10') plt.title('Year-wise Box Plot of Air Passengers') plt.ylabel('Number of Passengers') plt.xlabel('Year') plt.show() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](26-TimeSeries_files/figure-revealjs/cell-20-output-1.png){width=667 height=376} ::: ::: You can see the trends, median, and interquartile range of the data by year. --- We can also look at the seasonal subseries box plot that indicates the distribution of the data over the years for each month. ::: {#8d9bf8b3 .cell execution_count=20} ``` {.python .cell-code} # Draw seasonal subseries plots import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import seaborn as sns # Create a subseries plot for each month plt.figure(figsize=(8, 4)) sns.boxplot(data=air_passengers, x='Month', y='Number of Passengers', palette='tab10', hue='Month', legend=False) plt.title('Seasonal Subseries Plot of Air Passengers') plt.ylabel('Number of Passengers') plt.xlabel('Month') plt.show() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](26-TimeSeries_files/figure-revealjs/cell-21-output-1.png){width=667 height=376} ::: ::: --- We can also look at the seasonal subseries plot that shows the trend over the years for each month. ::: {#15b9e302 .cell execution_count=21} ``` {.python .cell-code} # Create seasonal subseries plot of monthly passengers fig, axes = plt.subplots(1, 12, figsize=(10, 4), sharey=True) fig.suptitle('Seasonal Subseries Plot of Monthly Air Passengers') # List of abbreviated month names month_names = ['Jan', 'Feb', 'Mar', 'Apr', 'May', 'Jun', 'Jul', 'Aug', 'Sep', 'Oct', 'Nov', 'Dec'] # Iterate over each month and create a subplot for i, ax in enumerate(axes.flatten(), start=1): monthly_data = air_passengers[air_passengers['Month'] == i] ax.plot(monthly_data['Year'], monthly_data['Number of Passengers'], marker='.') ax.set_title(month_names[i-1]) ax.set_xticks([]) # Remove x-axis numbers # ax.set_xlabel('Year') #ax.set_ylabel('Number of Passengers') plt.tight_layout(rect=[0, 0.03, 1, 0.95]) plt.show() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](26-TimeSeries_files/figure-revealjs/cell-22-output-1.png){width=950 height=370} ::: ::: --- We can also look at the autocorrelation plot to see if there are any significant lags in the data. ::: {#4f34fa41 .cell execution_count=22} ``` {.python .cell-code} from statsmodels.graphics.tsaplots import plot_acf # Draw the autocorrelation plot of air passengers plt.figure(figsize=(8, 4)) plot_acf(air_passengers['Number of Passengers'], lags=48, ) plt.title('Autocorrelation Plot of Air Passengers') plt.xlabel('Lags') plt.ylabel('Autocorrelation') plt.show() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ```
